title: Student's t-Distribution: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how to solve a problem involving the Student's t-distribution.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we have a sample of size 10 from a normal distribution with mean 5 and standard deviation 2. Calculate the Student's t-statistic for the sample mean.
hints: Remember to adjust for degrees of freedom.
problem.solutionHtml:
We'll follow these steps:

  • Step 1: Calculate the sample mean, \(\bar{x}\).
  • Step 2: Calculate the standard error, \(s/\sqrt{n}\).
  • Step 3: Plug in the values to get the Student's t-statistic.

subject: statistics
title: Student's t-Distribution
contentHtml: The Student's t-distribution is a continuous probability distribution that arises in statistical inference when the population mean is unknown and we want to make inferences about it.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we want to test the mean of a population based on a sample of size 10. We know that the sample mean is 5.2 and the standard deviation is 1.3. Assuming normality, what is the t-statistic for this problem?
problem.solutionHtml:
We can plug in the values to get:

  • t = \frac{5.2 - \mu}{1.3 / \sqrt{10}}
